awd_titl_txt: Determinants of Quantifier Interpretation in Typical and Atypical Child Language
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a project to study information that speakers convey by exploiting pragmatic inferences.  To understand what people say, one listens both to what is said and what is "unsaid". If there is a plate of 5 cookies on the table and a child eats them all and then tells her sister who made them, "I ate some of the cookies." the child is not strictly speaking lying. Notice that if one eats all of the cookies on a plate, it is also true that one has eaten some of the cookies on that plate. This "some, and possibly all" interpretation is given by the logic of what is said, while the "some, but not all" interpretation is considered to be a part of meaning that is unsaid and is appropriate in some contexts, but not others. Understanding when each of these two interpretations is called for is thought to be a question of which part of the mind is being put to use. The part of the mind that is dedicated to language only is thought to be responsible for the "some, and possibly all" interpretation, while higher order reasoning--not specific to language--is thought to be responsible for the "some, but not all" interpretation. When are children able to grasp this relatively subtle difference in language use? If science could find a moment in their mental developmental when they understand one, but not the other, it would constitute evidence of which parts of the mind develop more quickly than others. Further, do children who are known to have severe language problems show evidence of understanding one kind of interpretation and not the other? If so, not only would there be evidence of distinct developmental timelines for distinct parts of the mind, there might also be a way of identifying children with these disorders early so that they could receive therapeutic services to help them learn to cope with their language problem.

This study tests a sample of children who speak Spanish as a first language, because the difference between the types of meaning is clearer in Spanish than in many languages, as a result of there being a word with only the "some and possibly all" meaning ("unos") and another word for that can have either meaning ("algunos"). This project will examine what both typically-developing children and children with the developmental language deficit labeled Specific Language Impairment know about these constructions. Preschool-aged children with this language disorder are very likely to receive a dyslexia diagnosis once they reach school age. Consequently, one aim of this study is to identify differences--in terms of their knowledge of this aspect of language--between children who have language problems and those who do not, as a means for diagnosing language problems early in child development.

por.por_cntn:
In Spanish or English, depending on context, a sentence like Some kids went down the slide. can mean either a). “Some, but not all kids went down the slide.” or “Some, and possibly all kids went down the slide.” This type of fundamental distinction in meaning, or semantics, has been studied since Aristotle. Can children grasp these two meanings? Further, in adult English or Spanish, a sentence like Each Minion pushed a rock. is acceptable if there are, for example, three minions and three rocks and the individual rocks are paired with individual minions. We call this a distributive interpretation. Adults will not accept such a sentence if there is one rock pushed by three minions, which we call a collective interpretation. Children are known to take a relatively long time, until they are 10 or 11 years-old, to grasp this distributive interpretation of each.

 

As part of a larger “Nature vs. Nurture” debate in child language development, researchers studying what children know about quantity words like some and each debated for years how different children’s interpretations of these primitive components of our vocabularies are from adults’ interpretations. Did children know as much as adults and, if not, how old were they when they grasped these elemental units of meaning? In this project, we attempted to circumvent some of the well-known obstacles to a clear understanding. Fundamentally, we found that older 5 year-olds are adult-like in their interpretations of some, if care is taken to avoid important confounds. Each, in contrast, appears to take much longer to learn, until roughly 10 years-old, consistent with the existing research. Further, we found that the interpretations of both some and each depended on growth in multiple other areas of the mind.

 

What other areas of mind? We found that Spanish-speaking children’s understanding of some seems to be driven by (1) how big their vocabularies are, (2) how well they can pay attention (executive function), and (3) their understanding of quantity. We still do not entirely understand why interpretations of “each” take so much longer to become adult-like; however, it also appears to be driven by a combination of vocabulary, attention, and quantity knowledge.

 

What are the obstacles to showing what children know about some and each? We found that the experiments we use must include language that is very carefully structured to help children understand what question they are being asked. Further, children can understand some much more easily when it describes actions that are presented one after the other (consecutively), and not all at once (simultaneously), consistent with research on human memory and attention. Also, the pronunciation of some in English matters a great deal. When it is pronounced as “sm”, it is interpreted very differently from when it is pronounced as some. This distinction may appear subtle, but turns out to be critical to how English-speaking adults interpret some.

 

In our preliminary findings with children diagnosed with specific language impairment (SLI), we find that children in the SLI group have severe problems interpreting some in Spanish, and in fact consistently failed to understand even none and one, which we normally use as control items because typically-developing children as young as 3 and 4 year-old understand them.

 

In sum, Spanish-speaking children come to be adult-like in their interpretations of some by the time they are 5 years-old. A novel finding from our project is that this interpretation seems to click into place when children are able to produce roughly 115 different words in an unstructured 20-minute sample of speech. Further, the better they are at paying attention to what matters, not paying attention to what does not matter, and holding relevant information in working memory also contributes to how quickly they come to have adult-like interpretations. Quantity knowledge also matters for understanding of some and each. For English, pronunciation matters very much. Overall, vocabulary, attention and quantity develop and integrate as children come to have adult-like interpretations of these critical, fundamental components of meaning. Children with language disorders have marked difficulty in interpreting quantity terms.
